title: A Case of Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy in a 35-Year-Old Male
clinical_history: A 35-year-old male, who works as a software engineer, presented with a 5-day history of progressive weakness in his lower limbs. He initially noticed difficulty walking and standing from a seated position, which rapidly progressed to an inability to ambulate without assistance. He reports that the weakness started in his legs and has been symmetrical. The patient also complains of a 2-day history of numbness and tingling in his hands and feet. He has no recent history of travel, fever, or illness.

nprs.affected_area: Bilateral lower limb weakness and numbness

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or any physical activity exacerbates the weakness and numbness
picture: A 24-hour picture showing the patient's inability to walk or stand without assistance, with an inability to dorsiflex his feet
easing_factors: Rest and recumbency provide some relief
past_history: The patient has a history of a recent upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks prior to the onset of symptoms
medical_history: Generally healthy, with no significant medical conditions
medications: None, apart from over-the-counter pain medications which have provided minimal relief
personal_history: Married with two young children. Works from home as a software engineer, which involves prolonged sitting
imaging: EMG and nerve conduction studies (NCS) have been ordered but not yet completed. MRI of the spine and brain have been normal.
